data:
Facsimile Images

F̣lorentina ((·)) pia ((·)) bona ((·)) crestiana
dulcissimae coiugi ego Maius fec[i]
que ((·)) vixit ((·)) mecum an(nis) ((·)) XXIII ((·)) me(nsibus) IIII ((·)) di(ebus) ((·)) V
sene ((·)) nula querela ((·)) seper ((·)) in pake
5dep(osita) non(is) ((·)) Iun(iis)

Apparatus criticus

Text after Bivona

English translation

Florentina; pious, good Christian. I, Maius, made (this) for my dearest wife, who lived with me 23 years, 4 months, and 5 days without quarrel, forever in peace. She was laid down on the Nones of June

commentary

Mommsen suggested that this text was originally from Siracusa; however Ferrua (1940) identified this stone already in the antiquarian tradition at Rome (ap. Marini). Ferrua concluded that this is an antiquarian copy of a Roman original; Bivona is more circumspect and there is no immediate reason to assume that it is not the Roman original (however autopsy is required). One of Ferrua's principal arguments was the absence of an initial F on the Palermo stone and a vacat large enough to exclude its presence; however the lower part of the F is clearly visible in the photograph in Bivona.

bibliography

    10.7173 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000589 368 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002142 1948.0171 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283 Ferrua 1940 277-278 with fig.1 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002003
